Meet 35 year old Margaret who lives in the highland area of Kericho.  She is married and has 2 children.  She has been farming for 5 years to produce and sell milk,eggs, and tea.  She loves dairy farming because her cows produce a lot of milk and it brings in a lot of income.

Margaret chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because they have low interest rates and they also improve the standard of living of small scale farmers.This loan will increase productivity and thus provide income.

loans.use: to construct a dairy unit.

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Meet 35-year-old Allan. He lives in a town called Mpika, in the northern region of Zambia with his wife and 7-year-old son. He offers financial services to people in his community by providing the service of money transfers and bill payments.

Allan started running his business two years ago with the start up capital of $1,000, which he borrowed from some of his family. He has slowly built up his cash and is now working with a working capital float of $2,900. The proceeds from the business help Allan to provide for his family as it is his only source of income. He says running a small business without access to loan funding has been challenging. He has worked extra hard to insure that the business remains operational. 

Allan has requested a Kiva loan so he can grow his mobile money business to service more customers by providing a safe way to send, receive, and pay bills through his shop. He will add the Kiva loan to his working capital, which will enable him to serve additional customers.
 
Allan is confident that once he receives his loan, he will earn more profits and improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: to grow his mobile money business to service more customers in his community who need financial services.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Meet 29-year-old Hawa from Waterloo's eastern area in Freetown. She is married and blessed with five children.  

In 2009, Hawa established her sand business; she began her business because she wanted to improve her status of living. She works at the business from 8:00 am to 7:00pm, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and insufficient capital to expand her business.

Hawa requires a loan to purchase a truck to expand her sand business. 

She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and take care of her family welfare. In the future, Hawa plans to expand her business even more. 

She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase a truck to expand her sand business.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has three children. For the past year, Florence has been working hard to manage her small fish business, which sells dry fish. 

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 450,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase for more dry fish for sale, which will help Florence generate greater profits to take care of her parents. Florence hopes that in the future she will be able to educate her children. 

Florence is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase for more dry fish for sale

loans.name: Samali

texts.en:
Samali is 18 years old and lives in the town of Siroko in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has three children with one of them currently in school. For the past year,  Samali has been working hard to manage her small business, which does tailoring. 

To help expand her business, Samali has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more materials for making clothes to sell, and will help Samali to generate greater profits and improve on the family’s standard of living. Samali hopes that in the future she will be able to construct rental houses of her own. 

Samali is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more materials for making clothes to sell.

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa has been selling nipa (palm) huts in her village for eight years. Her business has been successful and she has earned enough to be able to repay her previous loan.  

Narcisa always finds ways to supplement her living. In 2011, Narcisa joined GDMPC to help her improve the quality of living and increase her ability to do  business. Recently, she borrowed a new loan to buy additional nipa palm to make roofing materials.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy nipa palm to make roofing materials.

loans.name: Marie      Z

texts.en:
Meet 25-year-old Marie from Waterloo eastern area in Freetown. She is married and blessed with two children.  She began her business to help her family. In 2009, Marie established her retail business.  She works at the business from 8:00 am to 7:00 pm, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and insufficient capital to expand her business.

Marie requires a loan in order to purchase more assorted drinks and pure water. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and renovate her shop. In the future, Marie plans to own the biggest shop in the community. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more assorted drinks and pure water.

loans.name: Claudia Yesenia

texts.es: Claudia, tiene 38 años de edad, esta casada, tiene 3 hijos y reside en el municipio de Santa Cruz de Yojoa junto a su familia. Ella siempre se ha dedicado al comercio, lleva aproximadamente 24 años de trabajar para generar sus propios ingresos.  Elabora y vende pan como semitas, torta de leche, quesadía  y otros, tamales con carne, artículos plásticos y otra mercadería que le encargan sus clientes.  ha mantenido estable su negocio mediante la inversión de varios prestamos, actualmente solicita el quinto ciclo que es por 21,000 lempiras para comprar materia prima como el saco de harina, manteca, huevos, leche, azúcar etc. , para la elaboración de pan y también otros artículos que le han pedido para la temporada. Su plan es poderle dar el estudio a sus hijos y ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar.
texts.en: Claudia, 38, is married with three children and lives with her family in the town of Santa Cruz de Yojoa. She has always been a merchant, working for the last 24 years to support her family. She makes and sells breads like semitas, milk cake, cheese bread and other things like beef tamales. She also sells plastic goods and other merchandise that her customers order. She has kept her business stable by investing money from several loans. Currently she is in her 5th cycle and is asking for a loan of 21,000 Lempiras to buy ingredients like a sack of flour, shortening, eggs, milk, sugar, etc to make the bread and other seasonal things that have been ordered. Her plan is to be able to send her kids to school and to help her husband out with their household expenses.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like flour, shortening, eggs, milk, sugar, etc for making bread and to fill other orders from her customers.

loans.name: Kevin

texts.en:
Kevin is a 21 year old farmer living in Kitale, an area with a high regional output of maize.  Farming has been his main source of income for 5 years.  He produces and sells milk and maize.  He enjoys farming because of the return he gets for the work.  The challenge he faces is that sometimes there are long rains or cold weather that destroy his crops. 

Kevin chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because of testimonies from other farmers of how Juhudi has helped them to improve their livelihood.  Therefore, he decided to give it a try and he found out that it was worth it.  Also Juhudi has flexible terms of loan repayment.

This loan will help him to buy a dairy cow which will increase his income and thus help him improve his standard of living.  Increased income will also give Kevin  a stable income when he gets ready to start a family.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anastase

texts.en:
Anastase is 47 years old. He would like to use Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase the farm's production. He wishes to invest the profits from his farming in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Montañuela Ii Group

texts.es:
María, tiene 42 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 4 hijos con quienes vive en el municipio de Choloma, Cortes. María siempre se ha dedicado al comercio, vende toda clase de mercadería como ropa usada, ropa nueva, zapatos, sandalias y desodorantes.  Este negocio lo tiene en su casa y vende por encargos. María ha solicitado un quinto préstamo en forma grupal por 10,000 lempiras para comprar cosméticos como cremas, lociones y accesorios para damas, y aprovechar la temporada navideña y obtener mejor ganancia. 
El grupo se llama Montañuela II que esta formado por dos personas María de blusa rosada y Oneyda de blusa color morado, ellas viven en la misma aldea, y se dedican al comercio, el total del préstamo grupal es por 15,000 lempiras. Sus metas son hacer crecer el negocio y mejorar su calidad de vida con sus familias.
texts.en:
María, 42, is a single mother of 4 children with whom she lives in the town of Choloma, Cortes. Maria is a merchant, selling all types of merchandise like used clothing, new clothing, shoes, sandals and deodorants. She runs her business in her home and sells custom orders. Maria has asked for a fifth group loan for 10,000 Lempiras to buy cosmetics like creams, lotions and ladies' accessories so that she can take advantage of the Christmas season to earn more money.

The group Montañuela II is made up of two people: Maria, in the pink blouse, and Oneyda in the purple blouse. They live in the same village and are both merchants. The total amount of the group loan is 15,000 Lempiras. Their goals are to grow their businesses and improve their families' quality of life.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics like creams, lotions and ladies' accessories to sell.

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is a married man, age 34 years, with three children, one of whom attends school. He lives in a rural setting with his family and one relative. 

He is a business man who deals in the brick laying business. Fred supplements his family income with a salary he earns from teaching; he started his business in 2000. He works 5 days a week and five hours per day.  

He has acquired this loan to boast his brick laying business, for his client’s different schools in different areas.

His future hope is to expand his business to serve a large number of people; his challenge is the lack of enough capital.  He describes himself as a hardworking and honest man, and appreciates what lenders are offering.

loans.use: To hire labourers and buy firewood to make bricks

loans.name: Suzan

texts.en:
Suzan is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past two years, Suzan has been working hard to manage her bakery business, which bakes cakes and bread. 

To help expand her business, Suzan has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more flour, milk and other items to be used in the process of baking bread, and will help Suzan to generate greater profits and improve on the family’s standard of living. Suzan hopes that in the future she will be able to construct a bigger house of her own. 

Suzan is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more flour, milk and other items to be used in the process of baking bread.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale  region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past year, Caroline has been working hard to manage her retail shop which sells drinks and nuts. 

To help expand her business, Caroline has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more drinks such as soda, water, and milk for resale and will help Caroline to generate greater profits and improve  the family standard of living. Caroline hopes that in the future she will be able to own land. 

Caroline is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more drinks such as soda, water, and milk for resale.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale  region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children. For the past year, Christine has been working hard to manage her retail shop which sells drinks and nuts. 

To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more  drinks such as soda, water, and milk for resale, and will help Christine to generate greater profits and take care of her family. Christine hopes that in the future she will be able to live a better life. 

Christine is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more drinks such as soda, water, and milk for resale.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 21 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. For the past three years, Lydia has been working hard to manage her small hotel, which sells cooked food. 


To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more food and tablecloths for the hotel, and will help Lydia to generate greater profits and take care of herself more to add in the business. 


Lydia hopes that in the future, she will be able to own a bigger business. 


Lydia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to stock more food and tablecloths for the hotel.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is 24 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past two years, Ann has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells beans. 

To help expand her business, Ann has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more beans, maize flour and rice for sale, which will help Ann to generate greater profits and pay for school necessities for her children. Ann hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Ann is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more beans, maize flour and rice for sale

loans.name: Asele

texts.en:
Asere is 23 years old and lives in the town of Tororo in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Asere has been working hard to manage her brew business, which sells local brews. 

To help expand her business, Asere has requested a loan of 350,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more pots, wood straws and millet for the business, and it will help Asere to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her child. Asere hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a cow for her son. 

Asere is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more pots, straws, and millet for the business

loans.name: Reycer

texts.es: Reycer tiene 56 años de edad, está casado y tiene una hija con quien vive en su casa propia. Reycer se dedica a la agricultura, se dedica al sembrío, producción  y venta de granos cacao y maíz, con experiencia de 15 años en el rubro, se inició con esta actividad a raíz que su padre era agricultor, le inculcaron desde temprana edad el oficio de la agricultura en el sembrío de cacao y ganadería. El principal problema en esta actividad es el factor climatológico de las constante lluvia que pueden perjudicar la producción y la  variación que sufre el precio de los granos, un día sube, otro día baja, pero gracias a su experiencia y sus conocimientos ha sabido sacar adelante la producción, lo que ahora espera  es aumentar las parcelas del cultivo  e  incrementar la producción de sus cultivos y tener una oportunidad de generar mayor ganancia.Reycer  con esta actividad sustenta a su familia mejorando su calidad de vida.Este es el primer crédito Kiva, por lo que Reycer  está muy agradecido y contenta por el apoyo económico recibido y la oportunidad  de  seguir creciendo. El dinero solicitado de S/.1500.00 está destinado para la compra de abono orgánico y mantenimiento de sus cultivos.
texts.en:
Reycer, age 56, is married and has a daughter with whom he lives in his own house.  Reycer is a farmer.  He plants, produces, and sells cacao and corn.  He has 15 years of experience in this field.  He started with this business activity because his father was a farmer.  They involved him in the agricultural field of growing cacao and raising livestock at an early age.

The main problem in this business activity is the climate.  The constant rain can damage the production.  Also a problem is the variation in the price of the grains.  One day it rises; another day it falls.  Thanks to his experience and knowledge, he has known how to get ahead with the production.  What he hopes to do now is to increase the crop land, increase crop production, and to have an opportunity to generate more income.  With this business activity Reycer supports his family and is improving their quality of life.

This is his first loan with Kiva.  Reycer is very grateful for and happy about the financial support he has received and the opportunity to continue growing.  

He will use the requested 1,500 soles to buy organic fertilizer and to provide crop maintenance.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizer and to provide crop maintenance.

loans.name: Ret

texts.en:
Ret, aged 52, is a farmer in Rokhak Kiri district of Battambang province. She started farming in 1985 with the purpose of earning the income she needs to raise her family. She realized that she needed to be involved in another business in order to make enough money to provide the basic necessities for her family and to educate her children to the required educational standards. That’s why she decided to start a business of selling mixed grocery products in a local market. 

Currently, Ret’s family doesn't have a safe latrine to use at home, so she would like to build one to improve their sanitation and personal hygiene. In this regard, she is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to build a household latrine and buy its accessories. Thanks to the water loan program offered by HKL with a special interest rate, it has encouraged her to focus on healthy living conditions in order to safeguard the health of her family and protect the environment.

loans.use: to build a household latrine and buy its accessories.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María, de 59 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora y luchadora, es viuda, tiene 03 hijos de los cuales solo una de 25 años de edad vive a su lado en su casa propia, todos los días trabaja mucho para tener una mejor calidad de vida. El trabajo de María actualmente consiste en el alquiler de cuartos. Ha establecido en su terreno 7 cuartos que alquila para uso diario, semanal o mensual a precios cómodos. Para la construcción de estas habitaciones contó con el apoyo de su esposo cuando estaba vivo y de sus hijos quienes le brindan su ayuda desinteresada. Lleva en esta actividad hace 21 años. Ahora se encuentra en pleno acondicionamiento de algunas de las habitaciones, tiene clientes que le pagan puntualmente, algunos de ellos ya viven en sus cuartos permanentemente. Se siente feliz desarrollando su actividad porque generalmente puede recibir ingresos económicos diarios o  mensuales sin realizar esfuerzo alguno, además se siente muy tranquila porque puede colaborar con el sustento de su hogar, espera que le siga yendo bien para que pueda seguir trabajando con tranquilidad. En esta oportunidad solicitará S/. 1800, está agradecida y contenta al saber que sigue contando con el apoyo financiero que necesita para avanzar con el progreso de su negocio. Con el monto solicitado comprará mallas para cubrir las ventanas de los cuartos que alquila. Asimismo, comprará algunos accesorios de lavatorio y baño para acondicionar otro cuarto.
texts.en:
Maria is 59 years old and is a very hardworking woman.  She is a widow and has three children, one of whom, her 25 year old daughter, lives with her in her home.  She works every day to have a better quality of life.

Maria rents out rooms and she has seven rooms on her land for rent at comfortable prices by the day, week, or month.  Her husband helped build these rooms when he was still living, now her children help her.  She’s been doing this for 21 years and now has customers who pay on time and some of them live there full time.

She feels happy doing this because she can generally receive a daily or monthly income without having to work very hard.  She also feels comfortable because she can help pay for the household expenses.  She hopes that things will continue to go well for her so that she can continue to work in a relaxed manner.

She is asking for a loan of S/1,800.  She is grateful to know that she can count on this financial support that she needs to get ahead with her business.  She will use the money to buy screens for the windows in the rooms that she rents out.  She will also buy some bathroom sink fixtures to set up another room.

loans.use: to buy screens and fixtures.

loans.name: Carlos Adalberto

texts.es: Carlos de 26 años de edad habita en casa propia junto a su pequeña hija de un año y medio. Carlos se dedica al comercio desde hace mucho tiempo. Siendo él la cabeza de la economía del hogar. Carlos repara, compra y vende teléfonos de esta forma se gana la vida y es como lleva la economía a su hogar.  Carlos, ha tomado la decisión de solicitar este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de repuestos y accesorios para teléfono celular con el fin de mejorar sus ganancias y así dar a su hija mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Carlos is 26 years old and lives in a house he owns with his small, eighteen-month-old daughter. Carlos has made a living from retail sales for a long time, as he is the primary earner in his household. Carlos repairs, buys and sells phones, and in this way he makes a living and supports his household.

Carlos has made the decision to ask for this loan from FUSAI to invest in buying replacement parts and accessories for cell phones with the objective of improving his earnings, thus giving his daughter better living conditions.

loans.use: to buy replacement parts and accessories for cell phones

loans.name: Corneille

texts.en:
Corneille is 41 years old. He is married to a farmer, and they have been farming maize for the past twelve years. With this loan, he would like to buy more fertilizer to use during maize production. He plans to use the profit to buy extra land to cultivate. 

The agricultural sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer to use during maize production.

loans.name: Raban

texts.en:
Raban is 33 years old. He is married with three children between the ages of  two and fifteen.  He would like to use the Kiva loan to pay labor costs and buy fertilizer for maize production.  He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase  production. Raban will invest the farm profits so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors to increase his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizer and pay labor costs for maize production.

loans.name: Juan

texts.es: Juan  nació en la ciudad del Cusco y tiene 35 años de edad, ella tiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene un hijo, él es una persona trabajadora y responsable pues se dedica a brindar servicio de hospedaje entonces en esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar toallas, jaboncillos, sabanas y otras cosas más, él pertenece al banco comunal “COMUZONE III” de la Asociación Arariwa y promete pagar sus cuotas puntuales con mucha responsabilidad.
texts.en:
Juan, age 35, was born in the city of Cusco.  He is in a common-law marriage, and they have one child.  He is a hard-working and responsible person.  He provides lodging service.

He now needs the loan to buy towels, soap, sheets, and other things.  He belongs to the “COMUZONE III” communal bank with the Arariwa Asociación.  

He pledges to make his payments punctually and very responsibly.

loans.use: to buy towels, soap, sheets, and other things.

loans.name: Fidele

texts.en:
Fidele is 27 years old. He is married to a farmer. He has spent fourteen years in the business. 


He would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. 


With the profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future, he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 


The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Namonde

texts.en:
Namonde is 37 years old. She lives in a rented house with her four siblings. She is a micro-distributor for Coca-Cola, selling Coca-Cola products wholesale to local retailers and customers.

She has been operating her business for nine years. Slowly, she has increased her working capital but still has constraints on what she can purchase due to not having sufficient capital to purchase the soft drinks up front. By increasing her working capital through a Kiva loan, she can purchase additional drinks to sell and earn more income.
  
Namonde enjoys running her business because she interacts with different people and other small business owners in her town. The business is her only source of income, and it helps her to provide for her siblings’ school fees and rent payments.
  
Namonde is grateful for the opportunity to access the loan and is hopeful that the profits will help to improve her and her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase additional soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Liliana

texts.es:
Liliana tiene 28 años de edad, vive en el caserío El Chorro, una zona rural de Morropon, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y animales menores a dos horas de la ciudad de Piura, costa norte de Perú.

Ella se dedica a la venta de comida preparada, es conocida por el buen sabor que ofrece en cada uno de sus platos, su negocio está ubicado en su domicilio, ha solicitado un préstamo de 1 000 nuevos soles para arreglar el local de su negocio y de esta manera tener un lugar agradable para acoger a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Liliana is 28 years old and lives in the village of El Chorro, a rural section of Morropon. Her town is known for agriculture, trade, and breeding small animals. This community is located two hours away from the city of Piura, which is on the northern coast of Peru.

Liliana sells prepared food and is known for the good flavor that each of her dishes offers. Her business is located in her home. Liliana is requesting a loan of 1,000 PEN so that she can remodel the space for her business. This will create a pleasant area where she can welcome her customers.

loans.use: to remodel the space where her business is located.

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita is a grower of rice crops on her two point three hectares of rice farmland. She has been engaged to this kind of business for 22 years. Estelita is 41 years old, married and blessed with three children. Two of her children attend school, while the other one is married. 

Estelita wanted to keep her farming business productive and profitable, but her capital intended to buy farm inputs is no longer enough. For this reason, she is seeking a loan of PHP 30,000 which allows her to purchase fertilizer and insecticides and to pay for laborers who will perform some farming activities in her rice field. She hopes that through this loan amount she can improve the growth of her rice crops. With this improvement, she could sell her product at a better price which would enable her to have a better way of living and let her two children finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and insecticides and to pay for labor costs for her farming business

loans.name: Sulayiman

texts.en:
Sulayiman is a married man. He is 45 years old and has six children, three of whom are attending school. He lives in a rural setting with his family and one orphan for whom he is paying school fees. He is a farmer who deals in agriculture where he grows crops like tomatoes, beans, maize, and bananas, and he also has a retail shop which is his side business. He started his business in 2010.

He works seven days a week and 12 hours per day and started his business to increase his income. He has acquired this loan to boost his two businesses through hiring of labor to weed his gardens as well as to buy more retail stock. His clients are people living in his village and those from the nearby villages.

His future hope is to expand his income. The challenge he faces is unpredictable weather like too much drought that destroys the crops and sometimes very heavy rains that may also destroy the crops. He describes himself as an honest and hard-working man.

loans.use: to hire laborers

loans.name: Dora Alejandra

texts.es: Dora nació en la ciudad del Cusco y tiene 38 años de edad, ella tiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijos, ella es una madre trabajadora y responsable pues se dedica a la venta de pasamanería entonces  en esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar como por ejemplo cuerdas, cordones, elásticos, galones, listones, flecos, espiguillas, soutache, cintas y otras cosa más.  Ella pertenece al banco comunal “COMUZONE III” de la Asociación Arariwa y promete pagar sus cuotas puntuales con mucha responsabilidad.
texts.en: Dora, 38, was born in Cusco. She is married with two children. She is a hardworking and responsible mother who sells decorative trim. She asks for a loan to buy, for example, ropes, cords, elastics, stripes, slats, fringe, spikelets, decorative braids, ribbons and other things. She belongs to the village bank COMUZONE III, part of the Arariwa Association, and promises to make her payments punctually and responsibly.

loans.use: to buy things like ropes, cords, elastics, stripes, slats, fringe, spikelets, decorative braids, ribbons and other things.

loans.name: Eben-Ezer Group

texts.es:
Doña Cruz es  una señora casada de 46 años de edad, quien vive junto a su esposo y sus nueve hijos en el Departamento de Sololá. Actualmente doña Cruz es la representante del Grupo Eben-Ezer, ella es la primera que se encuentra ubicada en la parte derecha de la fotografía. 

Ella es una mujer trabajadora que lucha por el bienestar de su familia. Actualmente se dedica a la elaboración de ropa típica, que es utilizado por las mujeres de su región. Eligió esta actividad porque es rentable y se obtienen buenas ganancias, es como de esta manera puede ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de su familia.

Comenta que lleva 17 años en esta labor, que hasta el momento ha sido bastante productiva. Es por ello que ha decidido conformar un grupo de mujeres con el propósito de mejorar la economía de sus familias. Por lo que ahora están solicitando un préstamo para la compra de hilos  y jaspeado (hilo teñido)  que servirá para la elaboración de la ropa típica.   

Su sueño es ampliar su negocio de ropa típica para generar más ganancias y de esta manera darles una educación de calidad a sus hijos, como también mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Cruz is a married woman, 48 years old, who lives with her husband and their nine children in Sololá department. Currently Cruz is the representative of the Eben-Ezer communal bank. In the photo, she is the first one on the right.

She is a hard-working woman who strives for her family's well-being. At present, she makes traditional clothing, which is used by the women in her region. She chose this activity because it is profitable and the earnings are good. In this way she can help her husband with the family's expenses.

She says that she has been doing this work for 17 years, and so far it has been quite productive. This is why she has decided to form a group of women, with the aim of improving the finances of their families. So now they are requesting a loan to buy thread and jaspeado (thread dyed to look like jasper or marble) which will be used in the making of the traditional clothing. 

Her dream is to expand her traditional clothing business in order to generate more earnings. This way she can provide a quality education for her children, and also improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy thread and jaspeado (dyed thread) for making traditional clothing.

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia is 20 years old and lives in the town of Tororo in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past year, Sofia has been working hard to manage her tailoring business. 

To help expand her business, Sofia has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more materials for making clothes to sell and will help Sofia to generate greater profits and take care of her family's basic needs. Sofia hopes that in the future she will be able to become a well known designer. 

Sofia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more materials for making clothes to sell

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is 17 years old and lives in the town of Siroko in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is single and has two children. For the past two years, Pauline has been working hard to manage her boutique, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Pauline has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase new clothes to sell, and will help Pauline to generate greater profits and take good care of her children. Pauline hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Pauline is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase new clothes to sell.

loans.name: Agali

texts.en:
Agali is 20 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past two years, Agali has been working hard to manage her small charcoal business.



To help expand her business, Agali has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sacks of charcoal to sell, and will help Agali to generate greater profits and improve on the family’s standard of living. 


Agali hopes that in the future, she will be able to construct rental houses of her own. 


Agali is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy blouses, skirts, pants, underwear, etc.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es: Martha de 36 años de edad es madre soltera de una niña de 4 años y un niño de 16 años de edad. Ella trabaja muy duro para dar a sus hijos mejores condiciones de vida. Desde hace 16 años se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza tales como lociones, champú, cremas, desodorante, etc. Este negocio es su única fuente de ingresos y de esta forma ha logrado sacar adelante a sus hijos. Desea mejorar sus ingresos por lo que solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de mayor mercadería (lociones, cremas, desodorantes, champú, etc.). Confía que los ingresos que obtendrá logrará cancelar el crédito y mejorar su calidad de vida y la de sus hijos ya que espera incrementar sus ventas y sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Martha is 36 years old and a single mother with a four-year-old daughter and a 16-year-old son. She works very hard in order to provide her children better living conditions. For the past 16 years, Martha has been selling beauty products such as lotions, shampoo, crèmes, deodorants, and other items. This business is her only source of income that enables her to move her children forward.

Martha wants to improve her earnings, so she is requesting this loan from FUSAI in order to invest in the purchase of more merchandise (lotions, crèmes, deodorants, shampoo, and other items). She is confident that the income she earns will allow her to repay the loan and also improve her quality of life and that of her children. Martha expects to increase her sales and her earnings.

loans.use: to buy lotions, crèmes, deodorants, shampoo, and other items

loans.name: Marlene Esmeralda

texts.es: Marlene de 21 años de edad reside en casa de propia junto a su compañero de vida. Ella se dedica a la venta de accesorios para teléfono celular y gracias a su carisma y buena calidad en los productos ha logrado ganarse la confianza de muchos clientes que cada día la prefieren más. Es muy reconocida en la zona donde reside como una mujer emprendedora, responsable y trabajadora. Su deseo es mejorar sus ingresos, y como toda mujer emprendedora ha tomado la decisión de solicitar este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de variedad y mayor cantidad de accesorios para teléfono puesto que sus productos son muy demandados y confía que con esta inversión logrará mejorar sus ventas y por consecuencias sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Marlene, age 21, lives in her own house with her life partner.  She sells cell phone accessories.  Thanks to her charisma and the good quality of the products, she has managed to win over the trust of a lot of customers, who prefer her more and more each day.  She is well-known in the area where she lives as an enterprising, responsible, and hard-working woman.

Her wish is to improve her income.  Like all enterprising women, she has made the decision to request this loan from FUSAI.  She does this in order to buy a variety and a greater quantity of phone accessories.  Her products are in much demand.  She is confident that with this investment she will manage to improve her sales, and, consequentially, she will improve her income.

loans.use: to buy a variety and a greater quantity of phone accessories.

loans.name: Zanabu

texts.en:
Zanabu is 19 years old and lives in the town of Bunghokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. For the past two years, she has been working hard to manage her retail shop where she sells essential food items. 

To help expand her business, Zanabu has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential commodities to sell and will help Zanabu generate greater profits and take care of her medical bills. She hopes that in the future she will be able to construct rental houses of her own. 

Zanabu is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more essential commodities to sell  in her retail shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy pork, roast pork, fried pork, sausage, etc.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 19 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale  region of Uganda. For the past two years, Gloria has been working hard to manage her small vegetable business, which sells fresh vegetables. 

To help expand her business, Gloria has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh vegetables to sell, and will help Gloria to generate greater profits and take care of her medical bills. Gloria hopes that in the future she will be able to become a rich lady in the area. 

Gloria is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh vegetables to sell

loans.name: Tunaweza Group

texts.en:
Juliana, who is currently running a retail shop for one year now, is married with five boys and a daughter who are in school. Juliana is in her mid-30s and works at her business from 8am to 10pm each working day. She is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This will be her second loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loan to buy more business stocks like sacks of sugar, maize flour, baking flour, waters, soda, packed juices, and other missing items. Juliana used her business profits to cover shelter, food, and medical expenses for her family. She also covered school fees for her children and has paid back her entire loan successfully. Juliana will use this loan to buy some liters of cooking oil, sugar, powdered and bar soaps, and other missing shop items. She dreams of buying a plot of land and building a family house. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "TUNAWEZA" which totals two members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy some liters of cooking oil, sugar, powdered and bar soaps, and other missing shop items.

loans.name: Saul

texts.es: Saul agradece a los inversionistas por el préstamo anterior pues le fue muy bien y él se siente contento por el apoyo brindado, él continúa brindando servicio de transporte público en la ciudad del Cusco. Ya son varios años que tiene al servicio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Saul sigue participando en el banco comunal “Conzume III” de la Asociación Arariwa y ya son varias veces que se presta crédito de la institución pero en esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para hacer mantenimiento del carro.
texts.en:
Saul is grateful to the lenders for the previous loan, as it went very well for him, and he feels happy about the support provided. He continues offering public transportation services in the city of Cusco. He has had the service for several years and it is going very well, thanks to the effort he puts into his work. 

Saul continues participating in the "Conzume lll" communal bank of the Asociación Arawiwa, and has already been granted credit by the institution several times. But on this occasion he needs the loan to do maintenance on his vehicle.

loans.use: to maintain his car.

loans.name: Lang

texts.en: Lang, aged 33, is a married woman who has been living Siem Reap province. To earn a daily profit, Lang has worked in the paddy fields since she was a young girl. Asides from this career, Lang also helps assist her husband with fishing activities along the Tonle Sap River. Together, they can earn approximately USD 9.00 per day and they often use it to cater to the needs of her family. They have been blessed with six children, four of whom are attending school.  As this is her fifth cycle loan with HKL, Lang will use it to buy a new boat and other fishing materials in order to keep her current business in a sustainable way.

loans.use: to buy a new boat and other fishing materials in order to keep her current business in a sustainable way.

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married and has three children. She is running a general store selling a variety of food and home use products in the local community. For three years in her business, Olga has earned well, meeting the family needs and successfully repaying her previous loan used in the business. 

Recently, Olga borrowed a new loan to purchase more grocery goods to resell. She was determined enough to improve her business to offer a better living to the family.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery goods to resell

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena is married with four children. She manages her own farm in the village of Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. Lorena has been growing coconuts for more than ten years and earns well for the family. 


She was able to successfully repay her previous loan used for farm fertilization. Recently, she borrowed a new loan to pay for the labor costs of weeding maintenance and plowing for a greener farm. 


In the future, Lorena hopes to help her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to pay for the labor costs of weeding maintenance and plowing.

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is 35 years old. She is a mother of four children. She would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and to buy fertilizers during rice production, she needs to buy more fertilizers in order to increase the rice production. With profits from her farming she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.  

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor during rice production.

loans.name: Alphonse

texts.en:
Alphonse is 31 years old. He is married and has three children. He would like to use a Kiva loan to buy fertilizer and cover the labor costs during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With the profits from his farming he wishes to reinvest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors to enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and cover labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sodas, soap, sugar and cooking oil to sell this Christmas season.

loans.name: Emelita

texts.en:
This is Emelita, 63, a resident of Batasan, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Rogelio, a pensioner, and they have children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Emelita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also sells round palm sized rugs for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

She is requesting a Php 15,000 loan to help her continue in the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Emelita dreams that her business will grow bigger and hopes to have a better living.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Jean Paul

texts.en: Jean Paul is 60 years old, and he is married with six children. He would like to use this Kiva loan to support his labor costs and to buy fertilizer to use to produce maize. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With the profit from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and to support his labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is 19 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has two children. For the past two years, Justine has been working hard to manage her small vegetable business, which sells fresh vegetables. 

To help expand her business, Justine has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh vegetables to sell, which will help Justine generate greater profits and pay school fees for her child. Justine hopes that in the future she will be able to own a bigger shop for business expansion. 

Justine is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh vegetables to sell

loans.name: Khodor

texts.en:
Khodor is a 48-year-old married father of three children.  He puts much effort into providing them with the necessary living needs.
Khodor opened his car mechanic business 23 years ago. He was too young when he first started working. Since he left school at an early stage, he was only capable of finishing his intermediate classes.
Khodor is a caring father and a beloved husband. He is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, to pay for doing necessary maintenance to his house to keep it a healthy living medium during the coming winter season.
This is his third loan cycle as an Al Majmoua borrower with a good standing history of paying back.
His previous loan helped him a lot in developing and improving his business in a way that it's capable of covering a good part of his family's needs and requests.
As for the future, Khodor hopes to keep on expanding his business, in order to make sure he will stay capable of providing his children with the best living and the education he couldn't achieve.

loans.use: to pay for doing necessary maintenance to his house to keep it a healthy living medium during the coming winter season.

loans.name: Florah

texts.en:
Florah is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of which is currently in school. For the past two years, Florah has been working hard to manage her retail shop which sells produce. 

To help expand her business, Florah has requested a loan of 700,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more millet, rice, beans and maize flour for sale and will help Florah to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her child. Florah hopes that in the future she will be able to own her residential house. 

Florah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more millet, rice, beans, and maize flour for sale.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 17 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. For the past two years, Betty has been working hard to manage her small vegetable business which sells fresh vegetables. 

To help expand her business, Betty has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh vegetables to sell and will help Betty to generate greater profits and take care of her family's basic needs. Betty hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Betty is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and is a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more fresh vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es: Juan Carlos mayor de edad casado con tres hijos menores de edad originario del municipios de chinandega, zona ubicada en el occidente del país, se dedica a la compra venta de mercadería en general como: cosméticos, zapatos, prendas de oro, plata, bronce, chinerias, ropa interior para damas, adornos y otros, sus compras las realiza en otro departamento el cual compra al contado y luego distribuye a comerciantes en distintos lugares del municipios y comarcas de chinandega, tiene clientes fijos y eventuales sus ventas son al contado y al crédito, la mayor parte de su mercaderías siempre están en cuentas por cobrar, los cuales recupera semanal y quincenal, se caracteriza por ser un hombre responsable, trabajador, con muchos deseos de superación personal, uno de sus sueños es poder ver a sus hijos coronar una carrera universitaria algo que el no logro hacer, el objetivo de este crédito es para capital de trabajo para invertir en las compras de mercadería en general ya que se aproximan las fechas navideñas y sus demandas han crecido y de esa manera poder suplir a sus clientes y brindarles una mejor atención. Juan carlos agradece mucho el apoyo que los inversionistas kivas les ofrece a personas de bajos recursos económicos.
texts.en:
Juan Carlos is married and has three young children.  He is from the Department of Chinandega, located in the western part of the country.  He buys and sells general merchandise such as cosmetics, shoes, jewelry made of gold, silver, and bronze, knick-knacks, women's underwear, decorations, etc. He buys his merchandise in a different department and pays cash and then distributes to merchants in different places within the municipalities and regions of Chinandega. He  has regular and occasional customers, and his sales are for both cash and credit. Most of his goods are in accounts receivable and he is paid either weekly or bi-weekly. 

Juan Carlos is a responsible, hard-working man, with a strong desire for self-improvement.  One of his dreams is to be able to see his children complete a university degree - something he was not able to do.  The purpose of this loan is for working capital to invest in the purchase of general merchandise since the Christmas holidays are approaching and demand has increased.  In this way he will be able to supply his clients and provide them with better service. Juan Carlos is very grateful for the support that Kiva investors provide for people of limited economic resources.

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of general merchandise such as various styles of clothing, cosmetics, shoes, etc.

loans.name: Alfredo Antonio

texts.es: Alfredo de 40 años de edad habita en casa propia junto a su grupo familiar el cual está conformado por su compañera de vida y su pequeña hija de 10 meses de edad. Desde hace mucho tiempo se dedica a la venta de dulces, chicles, bombones y chocolates de manera ambulante. Todos los días recorre todas las zonas de su localidad para ofrecer sus productos. Desea invertir en mayor cantidad de productos ya que últimamente no logra satisfacer la demanda y tiene la confianza que de esta manera logrará incrementar sus ventas y de igual forma sus ganancias. Por lo anterior solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de variedad de dulces, chicles, bombones, chocolates, etc. confía que con esta inversión logrará su objetivo.
texts.en:
Alfredo is 40 years old and lives in a house he owns with his family, which consists of his life partner and their small, 10-month-old daughter. He has made a living by selling sweets, chewing gums, bonbons and chocolates in an itinerant fashion for a long time. He travels around his entire area every day to offer his products. 

He wants to invest in a greater quantity of products, as lately he hasn't been able to satisfy the demand. He has confidence that he will be able to increase his sales and likewise his earnings in this way. This is why he is asking for this loan from FUSAI to invest in buying a variety of sweets, chewing gums, bonbons, chocolates, etc. He trusts that he will achieve his objective with this investment.

loans.use: to buy a variety of sweets, chewing gums, bonbons, chocolates, etc.

loans.name: Nelson Mauricio

texts.es: Nelson de 49 años de edad habita en casa de su propiedad junto a su hija de 18 años de edad y un hijo de 13 años de edad.  Nelson se dedica a la  fabricación de cocinas de metal de forma artesanal y con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado adecuar su pequeña fábrica de cocinas metálicas en su hogar de residencia. Es un hombre muy trabajador y responsable y gracias a su carisma ha logrado ganarse la confianza de muchos clientes que cada día prefieren más sus productos. Solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de materiales como: lamina lisa, alambre, estaño, etc. para la elaboración de las cocinas.
texts.en:
Nelson is 49 years old and lives in his own home with his 18-year-old daughter and 13-year-old son. Nelson makes handmade metal stoves. With a great deal of effort he has managed to equip his small metal stove workshop in his home. 

He is a very hard-working and responsible man, and thanks to his charm he has managed to win the trust of many customers who prefer his products more and more each day. 

He is requesting this loan from FUSAI so that he can invest in the purchase of materials, such as sheet metal, wire, solder, etc. for making the stoves.

loans.use: To buy sheet metal, wire, solder, etc.

loans.name: Yoni Raquel

texts.es: Yoni  es una mujer emprendedora quien a sus 40 años se dedica a la venta de verduras teles como tomates, cebollas, zanahorias y chiles. El negocio lo tiene adecuado en el mercado de su localidad y por mucho tiempo ha sido su única fuente de ingresos. Desea mejorar sus ingresos por lo que ha tomado la decisión de invertir en su negocio en la compra de mayor cantidad de verduras para satisfacer una mayor demanda. Solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de verduras (tomates, cebollas, zanahorias, chiles, etc.), espera resultados favorables ya que su sueño es poder dar a su hija de 11 años de edad mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en: Yoni is an enterprising woman, who, at 40 years old sells vegetables such as tomatoes, onions, carrots, and chili peppers.  The business does well enough in a local market, and has been her only source of income for a long time. She wants to increase her income and has made the decision to invest in her business by buying larger quantities of vegetables to satisfy the growing demand.  She is asking FUSAI for this loan to buy vegetables (tomatoes, onions, carrots, chili peppers, etc.). She expects good results as her dream is to give her 11 year-old daughter a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, onions, carrots, chili peppers, etc.

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
This is Maribeth, 37, resident of Batasan, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Ranny and they have children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Maribeth is a fish vendor. She buys different kinds of fish at wholesale prices and sells them by the kilo. She buys fish at the local fish port early in the morning. There are many patrons who prefer her products since they are assured of its freshness and cleanliness. Her store is located in a temporary fish market. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more fish to be sold every day. 

Maribeth hopes that her business will continue its growth and dreams that her husband will have a stable job. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for different kinds of fish to be sold in the market.

loans.name: Jean Claude

texts.en:
Jean Claude is 42 years old. He is married to a farmer and they both depend on rice farming. Jean Claude has been a farmer since 1998. He would like to use this Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase rice production. With the profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 42 years old. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase the farm's production. He wishes to invest the resulting profits in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 29-year-old hardworking man with one child aged three and a half living in Fort Portal, Uganda. His main business is motorcycle transportation alongside farming in order to earn extra income. He started business with a vision of managing to provide for his family. He is facing a challenge of poor roads especially the rainy season whereby he is always in the garage for motorcycle repair. However, he hopes to construct a residential house. Stephen needs a loan to buy a new motorcycle to transport his customers.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle to transport his customers.

loans.name: Karen Yamileth

texts.es:
Karen se encuentra en una relación en unión libre, tiene 23 años de edad y es ama de casa y agricultora, madre de 2 hijos el mayor de 8 años y acaba de terminar el segundo años de primaria preparándose para el próximo año a su tercer grado y una niña de 5 años de edad. Su ingreso depende del cultivo de maíz y plátano que junto a su esposo realizan para salir adelante actividad que aprendió desde muy temprana edad gracias a sus padres quienes son comerciantes y agricultores por generaciones. La tierra que juntos trabajan es propia la cual está ubicada a unos pocos metros de distancia de su casa de habitación a la cual se trasladan caminando para dar asistencia, mantenimiento y al final de cada cosecha obtener las ganancias esperadas para poder seguir apoyando a sus hijos en sus estudios, la alimentación, vestimenta, medicina con muchas restricciones entre otros.  
Sus planes y metas para el futuro, son los de seguir ampliando sus cultivos de maíz y plátano ya que actualmente tiene un pedazo de tierra el cual sembrara con una variedad de producto. Como madre, apoyar a sus hijos en sus estudios y convertirlos en buenos profesionales para que el día de mañana pueda tener mejores oportunidades en la vida y mejores ideas de negocios. 
Por lo que hoy en día ella ha solicitado financiamiento para la compra de insumos, mantenimiento que incluye la fertilización, limpieza, mano de obra en sus cultivos de plátano y maíz logrando de esta forma proteger y al final de cada temporada obtener una excelente cosecha.
texts.en:
Karen is currently in an open relationship, she is 23 years old, and is a caretaker and farmer. She is also the mother of two children, the oldest is a boy of 8 years who is finishing second grade and is preparing for third grade, and a girl of 5 years. Her income depends on the corn and plantain harvest, which she works at together with her husband in order to get ahead. She learned this trade from an early age at an early age thanks to her parents, who have worked as farmers for generations. The land they work together is their own and is located just a few meters from their home from which they walk to look after, maintain, and finally with each harvest they gain the income they've waited for in order to keep supporting their children in their studies, providing food, clothing, medicine, and other items within limits. 

Their plans and goals for the future are to keep expanding their crops of corn and plantain now that they already have a plot of land which they plant with a variety of crops. As a mom, supporting her children in their studies and raising them to be good professionals so that in the future they will have greater opportunities in life and a better understanding of business.

For these reasons she is now requesting a loan in order to purchase supplies for maintaining her land by fertilizing, cleaning, and labor for harvesting corn and plantains, and thereby protecting each season's crops and obtaining an excellent harvest.

loans.use: to purchase supplies and maintain her crops of corn and plantain.

loans.name: Delmy Del Rosario

texts.es: Delmy de 41 años de edad habita en casa propia junto a su esposo y sus hijas de 18 años y 11 años de edad. Desde hace mucho tiempo Delmy logró establecer una pequeña tienda en su lugar de residencia desde hace muchos años lo cual ya cuanta con mucha experiencia en el negocio. Muchas personas de su comunidad dan buenas referencias de Delmy ya que es una mujer emprendedora, responsable y trabajadora. Desea mejorar sus ventas para lo cual necesita incrementar su inventario para satisfacer una mayor demanda de mercado. Solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de mercadería para tienda tales como: golosinas, arroz, azúcar, frijoles, pan dulce, entre otros productos. Espera poder mejorar sus ventas e ingresos y así mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Delmy is 41 years old and lives in her own house with her husband and daughters who are 18 and 11 years old. A long time ago Delmy was able to set up a small store in her house and she now has a lot of experience with the business. Many people in her neighborhood speak highly of her because she is responsible, enterprising and hardworking.

She must increase her inventory because she wants to increase her sales to satisfy the growing market demand. She is asking FUSAI for this loan to invest in merchandise for her store such as: snacks, rice, sugar, beans, sweet bread, among other products. She hopes to increase her sales and income and thereby improve her and her family's quality of life.

loans.use: to buy snacks, rice, sugar, beans, sweet bread, etc.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is 17 years old and lives in the town of Tororo in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past two years, Juliet has been working hard to manage her boutique, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Juliet has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more new clothes to sell, which will help Juliet generate greater profits and improve the family's stardand of living. Juliet hopes that in the future she will be able to own a bigger boutique. 

Juliet is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more new clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy basic grains, potatoes, chicken, beef, oil and fruit for juice drinks.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 50-year-old married man and the father of five children. He has worked as a blacksmith for the past thirty years; it is his only source of income. Ali is a hard worker who puts a lot effort into developing his business and improving his family's living conditions. He started his business long time ago with his father. He quit school during the elementary stage to help his father in his business because he wasn't able to pay his educational expenses. Ali is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to buy the necessary iron pillars for a new project he is working on. Ali hopes to keep getting projects so he can provide his children with the necessary education that he couldn't acquire for himself.

loans.use: to buy iron pillars for a new project.
